sn22.123:1.1: At one time Venerable Sāriputta and Venerable Mahākoṭṭhita were staying near Varanasi, in the deer park at Isipatana.
sn22.123:1.2: Then in the late afternoon, Venerable Mahākoṭṭhita came out of retreat, went to Venerable Sāriputta, bowed, sat down to one side, and said:
sn22.123:2.1: “Reverend Sāriputta, what things should a learned mendicant rationally apply the mind to?”
sn22.123:2.2: “A learned mendicant should rationally apply the mind to these five grasping aggregates as impermanent … as not-self.
sn22.123:2.4: That is, the grasping aggregates of form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness.
sn22.123:2.5: A learned mendicant should rationally apply the mind to these five grasping aggregates as impermanent … as not-self.
sn22.123:2.6: It’s possible that a learned mendicant who rationally applies the mind to the five grasping aggregates will realize the fruit of stream-entry.”
sn22.123:3.1: “But Reverend Sāriputta, what things should a mendicant stream-enterer rationally apply the mind to?”
sn22.123:3.2: “A mendicant stream-enterer should also rationally apply the mind to these five grasping aggregates as impermanent … as not-self.
sn22.123:3.3: It’s possible that a mendicant stream-enterer who rationally applies the mind to the five grasping aggregates will realize the fruit of once-return.” …
sn22.123:3.4: “It’s possible that a mendicant once-returner who rationally applies the mind to the five grasping aggregates will realize the fruit of non-return.” …
sn22.123:3.5: “It’s possible that a mendicant non-returner who rationally applies the mind to the five grasping aggregates will realize the fruit of perfection.”
sn22.123:4.1: “But Reverend Sāriputta, what things should a perfected one rationally apply the mind to?”
sn22.123:4.2: “Reverend Koṭṭhita, a perfected one should rationally apply the mind to the five grasping aggregates as impermanent, as suffering, as diseased, as a boil, as a dart, as misery, as an affliction, as alien, as falling apart, as empty, as not-self.
sn22.123:4.3: A perfected one has nothing more to do, and nothing that needs improvement.
sn22.123:4.4: Still, these things, when developed and cultivated, lead to blissful meditation in the present life, and also to mindfulness and situational awareness.”
